segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 The talk is basically about two things and I co-founded a company called Outflank in
offensive security and during the years we've had many different people come to us asking
well, what did you do?
How did you approach?
What was the reasoning behind it?
So a part of this talk is to give a little bit of background on, well, our experience
that hopefully you can translate into your own career.
Another thing of the talk, and that's the first part that I will be covering, is if
I look at the current offensive part of the InfoSec community, I think that we are at
a certain tipping point.
Things change every so many years, but right now I think that things have changed significantly
and I'll be telling you a bit more about what is happening, but yeah, I think it's important
to recognize where we are in the moment of time right now, so you can maybe see there's
a little bit of a zeitgeist type of thing.
One final thing, yesterday and even the day before, several people approached me saying
well I'm really looking forward to this talk and I don't get it, again, it's not going
to be a technical talk, it's only about business type of stuff, but Blaise, Jean, Sam, I told
you yesterday several times that Sam, maybe you can give this talk as well, given the
stuff that you said at the bar, Stefan, several of those, I hope I did not disappoint you,
I hope I can give you a few pointers on maybe being an entrepreneur yourself.
Because this talk will be a lot about my experience, I want to give you a little bit of background
about myself.
My name is Mark Smates, you can find me on Twitter on Markov IP, I've been exploring
the borders of internet and security since hobby-wise, like late 90s, professionally
I started back in 2006 as a pen tester back at KPNG, I've got a background in network
engineering which is still pretty awesome, but I decided that security is actually a
bit more fun than network engineering.
What's relevant here is that I've been an employee for several years back at KPNG, great
firm, I do not get the hate of people hating on big four firms because they are actually
really great firms where you can learn a lot, but I've been there for several years, I went
freelancing for several years, then I co-founded a company, so I've been an official entrepreneur
or founder, and as you may know or may not know, the company Outflank has been sold,
we sold our stock to Fortra, formerly known as Help Systems, and that is back in September
There's good reasons why we did that, and I will be talking about that as well, but
my experience also includes going from a founder, having all the freedom, and now back into
a bigger corporation, and actually in a very positive way.
The company Outflank itself, we founded back in 2016, we specialize in red teaming, and
during the years we have pivoted from only doing consulting red teaming type of things
to actually having a software product.
The previous speaker on the screen showed a few remarks, stage one is one of our products
which is part of our Outflank security toolkit, it's a software toolkit, nowadays 32 tools
which support other red team operators, it started as our own private arsenal of hacking
tools, nowadays it's a big tool set, and it supports other red teamers.
That is the main thing we do nowadays, we still do a lot of red teams engagements beside
that to keep our flying hours in that sense, but that's what we do.
You might know our blog, you might know our GitHub projects, we've got a few over there,
but there's a little bit of background of Outflank.
So every person has its biases, so do I, let me tell you a little bit, so we are doing
red teaming, we are doing red teaming on mature clients, and the world of mature clients might
be a little bit different, but it's where my perspective actually comes from.
So I am aware that there is many smaller firms out there not having a blue team, not having
a SOC, not having the capability of defending basic ransomware attacks, but the view that
I have is of a mature experienced red teamer on those environments.
It translates I think into the other areas, but please take that in mind.
There's a lovely windmill over here, also look at the colours, it's red and blue.
The reason that I put this in here is that there is this public debate going on within
the infosec scene, OST, not the Outflank security tooling, but the open source security
tooling, or the dumping of offensive tools.
I'm Dutch, I'm from the Netherlands, Dutch people are typically known for not trying
to strive for a zero-sum game, we try to find a win-win solution.
I do not have a strong opinion on the whole OST debate, I think there are pros and cons
for both sides of the coin.
I think it's a very valid debate, I think we should not be dumping tools just out in
the open, but I also think that the whole red side of infosec actually has a certain
place in the infosec scene.
So there are pros and cons to both sides of the whole discussion, so please keep in mind
while I will be explaining the rest.
Finally, basically my path is not necessarily going to be your path, keep that in mind,
I started a few years ago, things have changed in the meantime, but maybe the things that
I did or that we did might not work for you, maybe they do.
So please keep that in mind.
Okay, we're going to do something different, I'm going to ask you all to stand up.
Yes, I am.
Thank you, awesome, wow.
First of all, it's good for the energy for you, and the other thing is that you had two
days of technical talks, right, Gustav, you learned a few things, the majority of information
security conferences, pretty cool content, you go home, you do nothing, right, or are
you the type of people that start hammering down all the projects?
Okay, okay, cool.
I would like you to walk away from this conference with just one idea.
You will be picking one idea.
Could be something that you have seen in the last two days, could be something that has
been on your to-do list, to research some time, which is still there, but I want you
to pick one idea to say, well, it would be pretty awesome if I can finish this project,
or if I actually make this tool, or if I add this pull request to this public repository.
I want you to think of one thing that you will be doing over the next few weeks.
And I want you to think further ahead.
So let's say you've got this idea that you want to have a specific malware loading technique
that you actually want to be crunching out.
Cool, pick that idea, but think one step further.
How can you make money doing that?
Let's say you got on your to-do list that you want to do, you feel that you're a bit
on the backside on the Azure training, on the Azure knowledge, so you actually want
to do that specific Azure training that is out there.
Next step would be for you to maybe make the most awesome publicly available Azure
hacking cheat sheet.
Maybe you want to go freelancing.
One step further is, why are you not building a company?
Now, if you've got an idea, something personally for you, yeah?
I hear no screams.
I hear no yes, no?
Yeah, yes.
Thank you.
Thank you.
If you've got an idea, please sit down.
I will not be asking you to remain standing all the time.
If you've got an idea.
If you don't have an idea, you need to remain standing.
It's going to be a long time.
You're okay.
Okay, so current state of offset, this is my view.
You might have a different view.
I was just going through this.
I think that the year is 2024, and I think that the red side of InfoSec actually has
quite a challenge ahead.
There's two main things that have been happening over the last one or two years.
One is what I like to name no more possibility for Git clone YOLO to the A.
What I mean with this is that if you look at the whole red teaming approach, things
have become a lot more difficult over the last few years.
Three years ago, four years ago, you can just take any public GitHub project, use that in
your red team ops, and actually go pretty straight quickly to the main admin.
It's no longer anymore the case right now.
Why?
Well, EDRs, for example, we've got these pesky endpoint detection and response tooling or
XDRs or whatever you want to call it, but nowadays, these are a lot stronger.
Also, the whole red teaming industry has become a lot more detailed, both a lot more objects
to be aware of, but also a lot more detailed things to be known.
It has become more difficult to do proper red teaming.
Finally, and this is something that we are seeing really significantly over, let's say,
the last year, less tools are being shared publicly.
We've seen pretty cool examples today in this conference as well.
Tools are still being shared, but there is a significant risk.
Nick, I think that you said, well, let's say you release your tool.
In about six months, most likely EDRs will have taken up and it's burned.
You can do modifications, but it requires significant skills to do the modifications.
There are more tricks to that specific tool, but it will become a lot more harder.
As an effect, less tools are being shared.
So no more Git clone YOLO to DA.
Not saying it's a good thing or a bad thing, I'm just saying that it is happening.
Another thing that I see with our customers is that blue is becoming the new sexy.
It is really sexy and cool to start working in a blue team, which is fine, by the way.
Can I see hands, people working on the blue side of InfoSec?
Sexy.
Can I see hands working on the red side of InfoSec?
Oh, that's a lot more.
Okay.
Okay.
Yes, you are sexy as well.
Yeah.
What I mean with this is we've come at a certain tipping point, and there are several factors
here working.
But if I reflect on our customers of a few years ago, working in a SOC had its limitations.
Nowadays, we have proper EDRs working at a SOC, so there is actually a lot more possibilities
for the people working in a SOC on the blue side to actually make an impact.
It's becoming easier, but also more, how do you say, fruitful, more eventful to actually
kick out the bad guys.
It's now possible to do so.
More effective tools, more effective managers, there's more budget available, all kinds of
different reasons, but blue has become the new sexy.
Another thing, typically, if you look at how red teams operate or pen testers operate,
you got shorter projects, so you got really quick feedback learning cycles.
You learn by every time doing new things, smaller incremental steps, but you will get
better.
And we have seen this happening now at the blue teams as well, is where they are more
familiar with doing programming themselves, they got better tools, there's all this Jupyter
Notebook type of stuff, there's all kinds of tools available for them, and they are
increasing the pace, and they are learning as we go, as they go, as they iterate.
Having that said, I think there are two major results right now if you look at the industry.
There's more talent going to blue, which is actually not necessarily a bad thing.
But another thing that I'm seeing right now is that the typical role that the offensive
security has had in the past, and still has right now, is it points out issues in products.
We cannot rely only on the vendors of the products for fixing their own issues.
It takes a creative hacker mind to point out the flaws.
We've come from several years of red teamers, some exceptions over there, but the majority
of red teamers are just using public tools, not doing research themselves.
Have we not become a bit too much of red team tooling consumers versus actually doing research?
Have we not been neglecting our training capabilities on the offensive side?
And if that is happening too long, maybe we just lose the ability to do proper research
and share this within the community altogether.
It's a question.
I do not know the explicit answer, but I do know that it's not necessarily looking really
good for the red teams or the red side of InfoSec on the amount of knowledge that we
put back into the scene.
A famous person said once, change is the law of life, and those who look only to the past
or present are certain to miss the future.
I think that red needs to look at the future as well.
What has got us here will not get us there.
We need to adapt to be up on front of the whole evolution in that sense.
And I think generally, if red does not sufficiently adapt to the new future, that we will end
up with only just a few firms which are capable of doing proper red teaming.
What are those new facts?
I've got two.
One, red teaming is hard.
Invest or GTFO.
The time of using free tools out there only for getting your red team results, it's not
here anymore.
Again, my bias is for hacking the mature clients, but this eventually will also be happening
for the smaller clients.
Actually on the blue side, it's common knowledge to spend money on tooling to make your blue
team better.
On the red team, not always.
And if you look at the past, we have been at those tipping points at those moments as
well.
We have done this in the past.
I'm talking about commercial vulnerability scanning, Nessus.
You are not writing your own vulnerability scanning anymore.
You just buy Nessus.
Metasploit came to the markets.
When the first time they came there, I was like, yeah, I've got my private stash of exploits.
I don't need a framework like MontySploit or whatever.
Actually it was a really good solution.
And we even paid for the Metasploit Pro.
Big bounties, regardless of what you think of the quality of big bounties, but we have
adapted to this new norm where it makes sense for a company to pay money to have big bounties
coming in.
Commercial C2s, Cobblestrike being the most important one over there, we have come adopted
to spending money on a C2 framework.
I see a few positive things happening right now.
There are more red teaming paid tools.
I'm talking about, for example, UnballastKit and Evil Jinx, Nighthawk, obviously our own
product as well, Outflank security tooling.
So there is small parts of optimism in here.
What I'm not seeing, and those of you who follow me on Twitter, you have seen my few
questions over the last two-ish weeks about several topics, it is, if you are a offensive
R&D researcher and you do not have the wish to make a full product, but you have the knowledge
of making a custom sleep mask or a specific injection technique or a part of a offensive
product, where do you go?
Where do you go to make money?
I've put our name in here because we are working with several external developers and we take
their research and they get paid and we include it into the Outflank security tooling set.
So, doing this from the top of my head, but I think three or four tools of the 32 tools
in total are made by external developers and they are being compensated.
But what other options are there out there for those researchers?
Anybody?
Okay.
Second thing, new fact, and we, as Red, need to find a solution for this, basically boils
down to the whole OST debate.
We struggle with how we do public sharing of offensive knowledge.
Now, if we look at the future, look at the past, this was different.
Can I see hands of anybody who know what SAINT was?
Obviously, obviously, yeah.
SAINT was a late 90s vulnerability scanner.
It was also the start of a huge debate.
Why would you be releasing a vulnerability scanner that points out issues in systems
just free, out in the open, sparked a significant debate.
Mimikatz released in 2010, 2011, something like that, sparked a huge debate on should
you be releasing such stuff.
Well, it pushed the industry forward.
And if you look at the current OST debate, mainly because we have all kinds of APT groups
and ransomware operators using public tools immediately, and we've had this experience
as well.
Some of our public tools we know have been used in public hacking campaigns.
Things have changed.
And we, as Red, have not really solved this issue yet, correct?
Few positive changes, I see smaller trusted circles where things are being shared.
So the knowledge is still being shared, but now not wide on the open, but in smaller circles.
And the other thing is that we see more blogs coming out with explicit moments where there
is a reflection on how you should be defending against this, or the proof of concept code
is on purpose limited, so not immediately being abused by ransomware groups.
Small positive things.
How is that idea of yours going?
At least one.
I'm happy.
At least one.
Okay.
So I do not want to sound like a negative Nancy or like an InfoSec dinosaur or whatever,
because yes, several things are not really going really well for the Red side of InfoSec.
But there's also several good things happening right now.
First of all, knowledge.
I vividly remember when I started hacking at KPNG back in 2006, doing pen testing.
I was dying for more info to put in my useful commands.txt, my simple file where I had all
the knowledge that I was gathering through the years.
My colleagues who were working over there already for many years, they had like this
huge list of notes and explanations and all kinds of things that made them better at their
work.
I don't know how often you would add a user on an HPX machine, but once you have done,
you write it down in your useful notes.txt, you got the knowledge.
Nowadays, hackers recipes, blog posts everywhere.
It's really positive that you can just go out there and have that information like instantly.
There's schools, there's universities giving security masters and bachelors.
You can actually get trained into information security.
Another very positive thing is the significant growth market for Red teaming.
You know Tyberg, you know Dora, you know maybe the ART framework, all kinds of regulatory
demands, requirements of Red teaming or Red teaming-ish type of things being requested
for those companies.
Malware, sorry, ransomware is on the mind of C-level people.
So there is an incentive to actually have those services performed, very positive.
Another thing is that the infosec scene is very much interwoven.
It's very small.
So you can make a dent in this industry with just a few blog posts, just a few proof of
concept codes, things are being shared within this community really quickly.
Now if you accept that you do need some work, hard work, you can actually be part of the
change and I think looking at it positively, there is no better time for being part of
the change.
So that's the current state of information security on the Red side.
Let's talk about, I hate this word, entrepreneur, I just do not like it but apparently it's
a translation, but founding your own company or being innovative or doing stuff.
I think we should be doing more and I want to reflect on several examples where we can
learn from others.
Obviously I will be talking about my own company, Artflank, just in a little bit, going from
starting it up, scaling it up, etc.
But there are a few other examples as well of offensive security projects, companies,
things trying to make money that we at least should be touching upon.
Anybody know what this is?
Exactly, yeah.
I put in this example, SpiderLabs is a collection of different tools I believe, part of a company.
One of the tools that you probably all have used, if you've done pen testing a few years
ago, was Responder.pi, yes.
And how many of you paid the author?
Five-ish.
How many of you have used it again?
Yeah, okay.
So Lauren Graffy, I hope I pronounced your name correctly, one person making an awesome
tool for doing all kinds of local network relaying type of attacks.
At that time, 2016, he rightfully said on Twitter, well, there's all these consulting
companies making big money using my tools.
I know that I gave my tool away as an open source product, but it would at least be fair
to be compensated to some extent.
And he was making really big noise on Twitter on, well, say, well, give me money, it's only
rightful to do so.
I saw some hands.
I also paid him.
I was freelancing still at the time, and I gave him a few Bitcoin.
I tried to look it up, how much I gave him.
I gave up because I did not want to know, actually.
I also did not want to know what the current rate of Bitcoin is, so shut it, please.
I gave him a few Bitcoin.
All I hope is that he kept it and was having a big blast with it.
But there was a big issue in this, because if you ask companies to compensate you for
your tool, most often those are bigger companies.
Bigger companies have procurement departments.
Procurement departments want to see evidence or purchase orders for when there's money
leaving the company.
Otherwise, no money.
Open source tool developer saying on Twitter, I need money or give me money, compensate
me, no procurement, purchase order possibility, so there is no money coming in.
For Shadow Industries, I put this here as an example because I really love this model.
I think it's a very good combination of making open source tooling, compensating the author.
You give him sort of a Patreon type of setup.
You give him a little bit of money, and then you will get the newest additions, the newest
additions to the tools for the next 6 or 12 months first before these features also go
back into the mainstream open source.
I like this model, sad to see that it actually stopped working.
For Shadow Industries, it is terminated.
There is still GitHub sponsors possibility, but it is the same issue as it was with Responder.
Big companies want to have purchase orders.
If you do not have that, all you end up with is just money that is payable with a credit
card, and now we're talking about lower amounts of money.
And if that is okay for you as an open source developer, that's perfectly fine, but it's
pretty hard to manage an open source project.
I can tell you for myself, from my own experience, it takes a lot of time, and if you want to
have some compensation, then, I don't know, 100 euros a month is not really the type of
compensation that you're looking for.
Other example that I'm putting in here where we can learn from others is obviously Cobalt
Strike, and there are probably people here in the room that know Raphael better than
I do, but during the so many years up until him selling the company, I spoke to him several
times, and all we can do is pay great respects for the tool that he made, awesome tool, but
also educating parts of the industry with his video series, but if you reflect on how
he single-handedly made a tool of this magnitude and educated the entire industry, single man,
it's not doable anymore right now, is it?
Unless you want to have five years without any single day of holiday, but I think the
majority of people would require some extra help for doing client vetting, for product
security, for making the tool really doing heavy R&D, it is a lot of work.
So Raphael eventually made a choice of selling his company, right now it's not possible anymore.
You need to have a bigger team, I would say, to make a tool of that magnitude.
Those are other examples, I can tell you the most about what we did with Outlink, and then
we need to go back to 2016.
We started with four people, and I know the other three people from my time at KPMG, some
of them went freelancing, me included, and then we came together actually founded a company,
but look back at 2016, our goal was to make a red teaming company and have a little bit
of fun.
Well, both we achieved that, especially the fun part as well, but at 2016 in Europe the
market was not ready for true red teaming.
So we did a lot of pentesting as well, and we tried to educate the markets, and we just
wanted to build this company, and well, we had to wait a few years before red teaming
was a really big thing.
Back then it was an easy choice for us to just license Cobblestrike, if you have to
develop your own C2 framework, which is stable, is manageable, etc.
It takes a lot of time.
So we decided to buy Cobblestrike and have time left for putting a quality in everything.
Now back in 2016, I know that the first red teaming engagement that we did, I think we
sold it to the customer, it was a bank, and 60-70,000 euro for a multi-month red team
engagement, which the daily rate or the hourly rate at the time was about 150 euros an hour.
We did the project, quality in everything, quality from building the tools, building
the infrastructure, building the documents, the reporting, PowerPoint presentation setups
on with the weekly calls with the white team.
Anybody want to guess, when we calculated all the time that we put into this, anybody
want to guess how much, what the rate was actually that we got per hour?
We aimed for 150, how much did we actually make?
Spot on, 21 euros, yes.
Quality in everything, and it really pays out, because so many years later, you can
still use the same type of templates, but it's so much work in the beginning.
That's the thing that we really learned at the beginning, it's so much work.
It's fun, but a lot of work.
We had no name in the industry whatsoever.
Outflank was not existing, you start a new company, we did spend a long time on actually
making a proper good name, but we as persons neither had any name for ourselves as well,
so it was a brand new company, how do you make a dent?
How do you do that?
We spent a lot of time on the name, the organizational setup, the logo, etc., and we spent time on
actually being awesome for our customers.
We had no time for making a website, and this is where this just YOLO type of red hoodie
thing came in along, because all we did was took a stock photo of a few red hoodies, put
it on the website, said, well, website will be released soon, took a few months, there's
a telephone number, an email address, and apparently that stuck in the heads of people
that were interested.
There's a new red team and company, it looks so scary, so secretly, and in the end, we
just ended up with keeping the same type of red hoodie vibe.
That's why I'm wearing a red hoodie right now.
A lot of time was also spent on all kinds of blogs and research, by the way, I did the
official academic research Twitter poll asking what is the true color of a hacker's hoodie?
Apparently it's not red, but it is what it is.
We spent time on blogs, research, presentation, just first of all because it's fun, secondly,
not being part of KPNG anymore where it was not really encouraged to go outside and go
speak and point out flaws in different tools, we were finally doing this, having a blast.
I'm adding three names of tools in here that I personally created, but the iFlank team
did more in total.
The first one is invoke AD lab deployer.
It was a tool PowerShell based to deploy a Active Directory connected lab with all kinds
of systems.
It would take a basic Windows image, spool, set it up, do the network connections, install
office, et cetera, et cetera.
I spent months on this and it sucked monkey balls.
Nobody was using it.
Why?
Automation lab came along, did it way better, and there were all kinds of quickly after
that there were other tools to actually do automated deployment of infrastructures way
better.
Months on this.
I learned a ton, but on impact, nothing.
The other example is what I call net as age helper beacon.
It was a small project.
I spent about one hour on this.
It was a proof of concept, how can you make a cobalt strike beacon working in specific
DLL setup so you can put it into a Windows as a persistency mechanism with the net shell
as a helper DLL.
I saw a tweet.
I started investigating.
In about an hour the code was ready, put it on Twitter and GitHub and that actually made
way much more impact than the whole multi-month invoke ADW deployer did.
I do not understand why, but it happened.
It actually got listed on the MITRE ATT&CK framework, so yes, we are officially referenced
on MITRE ATT&CK.
Red Elk is another project which is a combination of both in a sense because it takes a lot
of time to make a proper project, but it also actually makes an impact in the industry.
My apologies.
It's not have been given the proper care over the last two years because we've been busy
with other stuff, but I promise you Red Elk will get a little bit more care, love and
tenderness over the next few weeks to months.
Stuff that we learned from the beginning was get ready for some serious hard work.
Starting a company is a lot of work.
It is also fun.
Do it with a good group of people, but it is fun to do just a little bit of work.
Learn to say no to clients, especially in the beginning when red teaming as a concept
was not really familiar, we had customers asking us, well, can you please go red team
our corporate website?
No, and you need to learn to say no to customers and actually try to educate the market.
Things were completely different back in 2018, but in 16 we had those type of conversations.
I would say marketing is key and regarding the project, I'm just going to quote Wayne
Grinsky.
He said, you know, 100% sure that you will not, you know that you will miss 100% of the
shots that you have not taken.
So just go out there, make your tools.
Some of them will give you some marketing value.
The other ones you don't, but you never know which one.
Fast forward 2019.
By then we have grown slightly, I believe, five, maybe six people, high performing, small
red team.
It's a small company, but most red teams are small in essence anyway.
So if you have a company of like six people, you can do multiple red teaming engagements
at the same time.
There have been moments where we were hacking all three major banks at the same time, which
is pretty awesome to be able to say.
We just kept on blogging and tools and conference talks, etc.
It's also about the time when we start making our own private arsenal of tools because the
public tools were getting less effective and we just had a few fun ideas.
The final bullet point, more than the technical tricks that you do, is also very much valid
in all the other years.
But anybody want to guess how much time, percentage-wise, over red team engagement you spent on non-hacky
hacky stuff?
60% you spent on non-hacky stuff, so 40% is only hacking.
You say it from experience?
No?
Whatever the answer is going to be, it might be different for different teams, but we are
about 50-ish percent.
And I'm talking infrastructure deployment, I'm talking discussions with the white team,
I'm talking actually presenting your results.
The actual moments that you are making the progress in the network itself, doing the
actual hacky hacky things, 50-ish percent.
Now, for those 50% hacky hacky stuff, there are lots of trainings out there.
When is the last time that you had a training on your social skills?
When is the last time that you had a professional writing course?
When was the last time that you had a presentation training?
It is actually really important, and it is important to, obviously as a hacking person,
technically you're always right because you proved that you got to the target, but getting
that message across is just as important, maybe even more important.
So being able to actually make that call, you might want to spend some time on this.
A few things that we learned during this time is that everybody expects you to grow significantly.
People were wondering why has Outflank not grown to 50-ish people?
Well, because we don't like it to be.
We enjoy working with a small team, bright minds, that is what we like to do, but the
industry expects you to be growing.
Well, F them.
